title: Mum issues warning after her two-year-old daughter cuts her legs in a pool leaving her bleeding
text:
A number of concerned mothers are warning parents of the dangers of 'sandpaper'-like pools after their children were left bleeding and in pain after a swim.

Katie Dowling's two-year-old daughter was received dozens of bloodied scratches from the harsh floor of the pool at the Burpengary Regional Aquatic Leisure Centre near Brisbane.

Ms Dowling's sister took her kids to swimming lessons on Monday morning, when the toddler grazed her legs on the pool's surface.

'My daughter sat on the edge of the little pool and slid down to the step below to get in. In the process her legs were scratched, bleeding and she was screaming in pain,' she said.

Scroll down for video

Katie Dowling's two-year-old daughter was left with dozens of bloodied scratches from the surface of a local public pool

Katie Dowling said that after recent renovations, the kids play pool's new surface has 'the consistency of sandpaper'

'She wasn't doing anything wrong. She entered the pool as any child that size would do.'

The concerned mother said that after recent renovations, the kids play pool's new surface has 'the consistency of sandpaper' on its sides.

'I believe (the aquatic centre) needs to review their choice of surface in the kids area to prevent further injuries occurring,' she said.

'My daughter is still in quite a bit of pain and I’m hoping her legs heal quickly.'

'She kept poking her legs out saying "ouch, ouch",' she told 7 News.

But Ms Dowling's daughter isn't the first child that the public pool has injured since its recent $5.4million upgrade.

Vicky Cozens' seven-year-old daughter (pictured) was also left in pain after falling on the bottom of the Burpengary Regional Aquatic Leisure Centre pool in April

Vicky Cozens told Daily Mail Australia that her seven-year-old daughter was in pain after falling on the bottom of the pool in April.

'It all happened within seconds really,' she said.

'She slipped walking in the shallow part. We have been there many times over the years before the renovations and had no injuries.

'What ever they have used is very nasty'.

Michelle Doyle Kennedy's kids also had a similar experience at the public pool.

'This is exactly what's happened to all the kids! They got cuts all over their arms and legs too from there,' she said.

Moreton Bay Regional Council reopened the pool in February this year after undertaking the major renovations.

A council spokesman told Daily Mail Australia that slip-resistant surfacing has been used to try to prevent fall-related injuries.

'We understand the concerns that have been raised with the slip-resistant surface that’s been used at the pool,' the statement read.

'Council officers have spoken with the girl’s mother and committed to reviewing the type of surface that’s been used.'

Ms Dowling suggested the council set up warning signs, as well as changing the surface to something less rough.
description: Katie Dowling's two-year-old daughter's legs were scratched and bloodied from the harsh floor of a pool at the Burpengary Regional Aquatic Leisure Centre near Brisbane.
authors: Alana Mazzoni For Daily Mail Australia
